titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jamaica Office of Police records 1977.096
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Jamaica (New York, N.Y.). Office of Police

did.abstract: The Jamaica Office of Police records span the period 1780 to 1782 and consist of three handwritten documents.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The records were formally accessioned in 1977.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Jamaica Office of Police records, 1977.096, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Jamaica Office of Police records span the period 1780 to 1782 and consist of three handwritten documents. Two of the documents concern the repair of highways in Queens County and Kings County, New York, while the third document states that Aaron Von Nostrant, Marshall of the Jamaica Office of Police, is empowered to inspect the weight and quality of bread sold in Jamaica.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This material is in the public domain.

While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
